NiO–GO and Ni–GO composites enhanced the rate of H2 evolution under mercury-lamp irradiation from an aqueous methanol solution by approximately four and seven times, respectively. In the procedure of forming Ni-loaded GO composites, a large portion of the GO sheets was reduced because of the NaBH4 reducing reagents and the annealing process. As a result, the cocatalysts assisted in the extraction of photogenerated electrons instead of enhancing the charge separation at the boundary between sp2 and sp3 domains.
The photoactivity of GO with various oxidation levels was investigated in Yeh et
al.221 Highly-oxidized GO has a large bandgap that decreases light absorption, resulting in a reduction in the photocatalytic evolution of H2 from water, compared to the performance of GO, which has a lower oxidation level. However, only highly-oxidized GO was able to catalyze O2 evolution under mercury-lamp irradiation in the presence of electron-scavenger Ag+ ions. This demonstrates that GO with a sufficiently high oxidation level is suitable for both the reduction and oxidation of water under mercury-lamp irradiation, in spite of the mutual reduction of GO leading to an upward shift in the VBM that results in a narrowing of the bandgap of GO.
Substitutional doping with group-V elements (e.g., N and P elements) into GO
can enhance the photoactivity of pure GO because of the induced charge separation.222, 223 Latorre-Sánchez et al. prepared P-doped GO (P-GO) through the pyrolysis of H2PO4 --modified alginate.222 The P-GO catalyzed H2 evolution at a rate of 12 µmol g-1h-1 from an aqueous methanol solution under UV–visible light (Xe-lamp) irradiation, which is higher than that of GO (1.5 µmol g-1h-1). Latorre-Sánchez et al.
also prepared N-GO from biomass for use as a visible-light photocatalyst for H2 generation from water.223 After 3 hours of laser irradiation at 532 nm, the N-GO
photocatalyst generated 55 µmol of H2 from an aqueous methanol solution. These

results indicate that the presence of P and N atoms in GO increases its photocatalytic activity.
The tunable electronic properties of GO enhance its potential as a photocatalytic
medium for photochemical reaction. As previously mentioned, graphene with amino or oxygen functionalities exhibits n-type or p-type conductivity.38 P-type conductivity hinders the hole transfer required for water oxidation and suppresses O2 evolution, whereas n-type conductivity hinders the injection of photogenerated electrons into the solution phase required for H2 evolution. GO is a p-doped semiconductor capable of stably catalyzing H2 evolution from an aqueous methanol solution under mercury-lamp irradiation.215 However, O2 evolution from the decomposition of water was not observed from GO with moderate oxidation, even in the presence of electron-scavenger Ag+ ions. Converting p-type GO into n-type GO by the introduction of amino and amide groups through an ammonia treatment at room temperature is a simple method to facilitate photocatalytic O2 evolution (Fig. 20(a)).224 GO and n-type GO were shown to steadily catalyze H2 evolution from an aqueous methanol solution under mercury-lamp irradiation (Fig. 20(b)). The amount of H2 evolved through the use of GO was three times that obtained from n-type GO. Conversely, n-type GO was shown to catalyze the evolution of O2 from an AgNO3 aqueous solution under mercury-lamp irradiation (Fig. 20(c)). Furthermore, n-type
GO simultaneously catalyzed the evolutions of H2 and O2 under visible light (λ > 420 nm) illumination, but with a H2/O2 molar ratio below 2. Experimental results show that the strategies for tuning conductivity in forms of GO can strongly affect the photocatalytic activity involved in the evolutions of H2 and O2.

The use of GO nanoparticles as photocatalysts to achieve overall water splitting
is the ultimate goal in the application of solar energy. GO was shown to be a p-type semiconductor capable of injecting photogenerated electrons into water to promote the evolution of H2. 215 The modification of GO by an ammonia treatment converted GO to an n-type semiconductor capable of facilitating hole injection for the oxidation of water to obtain O2. 224 The size effect of sp 2 domains resulting from quantum confinement was also shown to influence the electronic structures of GO.18 Thus, size modulation in conjunction with chemical modification represents an effective means of tuning the electronic properties of GO to achieve efficient water reduction and/or

sections.heading: 4.2.2. GOQD photocatalysts
sections.text:
The physical and chemical characteristics of GO nanoparticles, including the tenability of conductivity and electronic structures, indicate that modified GO particles with lateral dimensions of less than 100 nm are suitable for overall water splitting. A study synthesized NGOQDs into a single particle with both n- and p-type conductivities, which were attributed to nitrogen and oxygen functionalities, respectively.225 Fig. 21(a) presents the results of an electrochemical impedance spectroscopic analysis with the Mott–Schottky equation for identifying the type of conductivity associated with NGOQDs. The NGOQDs in Fig. 21(a) present concave plots similar to those associated with n- and p-type conductivities in semiconductors.226, 227 These results indicate the coexistence of both n- and p-type conductivities in the NGOQDs.

simultaneous evolution of H2 and O2 over NGOQDs, at a stoichiometric ratio, can be attributed to the formation of favorable bending in the diode system, which mimics the processes involved in biological photosynthesis.225 The intrinsic sp2 domains of NGOQDs serve as an interfacial junction between the n- and p-type domains, thereby creating charge recombination sites for the majority carriers of both n- and p-domains and promoting the minority carriers to perform water redox reactions at
semiconductor−water interfaces (Fig. 21(c)). This vectorial charge displacement
mechanism corresponds to the PL mechanisms characterized by transient spectroscopy, which exhibit strong charge separations in the vicinity of graphene-like states in GO.61
Yeh et al. reported the photocatalytic water-splitting performance of
surface-intact NGOQDs (iNGOQDs), which are also based on the abundant elements of C, H, O, and N.228 The synthesized iNGOQDs, when deposited with Pt as a cocatalyst, catalyzed H2 evolution from water containing triethanolamine (TEOA) at a QY of 12.8% under monochromatic light irradiation (420 nm). The activity of the iNGOQDs was among the highest of all photocatalyst types, including metal-containing materials. The high activity of the iNGOQDs was ascribed to the specific electronic properties of a p–n photochemical diode. An advantage of the iNGOQD photocatalysis was that the morphology and electronic structure of the iNGOQDs could be manipulated through simple nitridation and oxidation on graphene materials consisting of only C and H.

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Stability of GO-based photocatalyts
sections.text:
The photocatalytic stability of GO-based materials is a concern in the current stage of research because GO materials in water might suffer from photocorrosion through

self-oxidation by photoinduced holes, in which some CO2 evolved. 229 This corrosion reaction may lead to formation of vacancy sites and defects on GO nanosheets, and the H2 evolution rate decreased as increasing the irradiation time. By contrast, steady generation of H2 occurred when GO was dispersed in a methanol aqueous solution under irrdaiation.215 Reduction of GO occurred because methanol acted as a strong hole scavenger. The reduction was transient and the GO quickly became stabilized under irradiation. Previous studies reported the reduction of GO by electrons induced in other photocatalysts, such as TiO2 187and CdS,195 under light irradiation. The reduced GO formed linkages with the photocatalysts and stabilized them by trapping the photoinduced electrons. This strategies effectively improved the stability of the photocatalytic reaction system.
In reference 228, Pt-loaded iNGOQDs suspended in a TEOA aqueous solution
steadily generated H2 evolution under visible light irradiation for about 4 days, hereafter decay took place, attributable to Pt cocatalyst accelerating the electron transfer and damaging the QDs. When combined with GO sheets, iNGOQDs exhibited improved stability in the same photocatalytic system.230 Further design of the framework and electronic structure in GO-based composites to exploit GO sheets for electron trapping is expected to prolong the lifespan of a photocatalytic system.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and outlook
sections.text:
This review introduced GO-based materials as the media for photoenergy conversion from the perspective of PL, photovoltaics, and photocatalysis. The oxygen functional groups on GO nanoparticles provide opportunities to tailor chemical functionalities and tune electronic properties. The unique heterogeneous electronic properties of GO,

resulting from the presence of sp2 and sp3 domains, have been demonstrated in the time-resolved spectroscopic measurement of ultrafast carrier dynamics as well as from the results of tuning the surface chemistry. Tuning the surface chemistry by tailoring the oxidation levels, modifying the surface of GO, and implementing the substitutional doping of GO, demonstrated that sp2 and sp3 domains emit PL of short and long wavelengths, respectively. The ultrafast dynamics in time-resolved spectroscopic measurements illustrated the coexistence of sp2 and sp3 domains and the competing PL emissions between them. sp2 domain-derived PL emissions are bright and have short lifetimes, indicating that sp2 domains are favorable sites for charge recombination.
Except for the QYs, the properties of GOQDs are inherited from the GO,
although various strategies have been developed for tuning the surface chemistry with various electronic properties. The QYs of GOQDs are higher than those of GO because of the suppression of mutual quenching in the active domains of GOQDs. Additional chemical processing and modification could further reduce the competing pathway between radiative and nonradiative recombination. A combination of theoretical calculations and experimental results indicated that bandgap is not dependent on the size of the particles, but rather on the sp2 and sp3 domains in GOQDs.
GOQDs possess accessible triplet states resulting from the edge effect. Triplet
excited states have significantly longer lifetimes and tend to have longer diffusion lengths. In addition to a high extinction coefficient, tunable bandgap, and homogeneous size distribution, GOQDs synthesized by stepwise solution processes are suitable as sensitizers for solar energy conversion, with an efficiency comparable to that of some metal-based quantum-dot sensitized solar cells. top-down techniques are still somewhat low in efficiency when serving as sensitizers in optoelectronics, because of factors such as a large size distribution and the arrangement of pores.
GO sheets can act as photocatalysts or electron acceptors, depending on their
oxidation levels. GO sheets with a low oxidation level function as substrates for charge separation by trapping photogenerated electrons from metal-based photocatalysts. Further deposition of cocatalysts on GO sheets can help extract the accumulated electrons for the reduction of water in the evolution of H2. GO with moderate oxidation levels can function as photocatalysts for water decomposition. Oxygen-bonded carbon atoms are capable of dissociating excitons, thereby providing active sites for H2 evolution. Cocatalysts such as Ni and Pt enhance H2 evolution over a reduced GO that contains low oxygen functionalities. Modifying GO with ammonia can switch the conductivity from p-type to n-type, resulting in dominant O2 evolution. n-type GO is capable of simultaneously catalyzing the evolutions of H2 and O2 in a stoichiometric ratio different from water under visible-light irradiation. These results indicate that the types of functionalities on GO strongly influence the results associated with water splitting.
Tuning the electronic properties of GO through a combination of size modulation
and chemical doping can achieve overall water splitting. Suspending NGOQDs with n- and p-type domains in pure water can achieve the evolution of H2 and O2 at a molar ratio of 2:1. A photochemical diode-type mechanism for water splitting over NGOQDs uncovers numerous opportunities for the design of graphene semiconductor architectures capable of mimicking the vectorial charge displacement found in biological photosynthesis. Furthermore, NGOQDs consist of only C, H, O, and N, which clearly indicates that graphene-based photocatalysts could achieve the

photosynthetic generation of H2 through water splitting in a sustainable and environmentally-friendly manner.
The charge transfer mechanisms in PL, photovoltaics, and photocatalysis for
photoenergy conversion can be attributed to intrinsic sp2 domains and disordered sp3 domains. Intrinsic sp2 domains are induced by the size effect. A major factor involved in the manipulation of the electronic structure of disordered sp3 domains is the type of functionalities. The PL lifetime associated with intrinsic sp2 domains is shorter than that of disordered sp3 domains; by contrast, a long lifetime of electrons is required for photovoltaics and photocatalysis. Therefore, the precise control of sp2 domains to ensure that they are identical in size is crucial to achieving monochromatic emissions. The modification of GO nanoparticles using various functionalities can be used to tailor the sp2 domain size. In this way, the electronic structures can be tuned to alter the intrinsic bandgaps of sp2 domains in the creation of various emission colors. High QYs could then be obtained through surface modifications to promote the passivation of nonradiative sites.
Disordered sp3 domains drive the photoenergy conversion in photovoltaics and
the photocatalysis involved in water splitting, because the charge separation among the sp2 and sp3 domains or the triplet states at the edges lead to long electron lifetimes. Designing and engineering the electronic structures on the active surface of GO nanoparticles by changing the quantity and types of functionalities is essential to photocatalytic water splitting and photovoltaics. Currently, the photoenergy conversion efficiency in photocatalysis and photovoltaics remains low. GO nanoparticles with multiple functionalities, such as electron-donating and electron-accepting functionalities, can efficiently separate excitons and further stabilize photoexcited electrons, and represent a means of promoting photoenergy

conversion in the production of solar fuels and electric power.
Further understanding the mechanisms involved in electron-hole pair generation
and disappearance is the essential task for efficient photoenergy conversion. Previous studies have demonstrated that the PL emissions are associated with intrinsic sp2 and/or disordered sp3 domains. Further investigations on the transport dynamics of charges separated at the sp2-sp3 domain interface and the influence of structural defects on transportation are required. The first challenge for enhancing PL efficiency is to develop a synthetic route for GO nanomaterials containing intact sp2 domains that minimize the probability of non-radiative charge recombination. The second challenge is the precise control of oxygen functionalities on the GO nanomaterials, therefore designing architectures for efficient electron-hole separation. Tuning the quantities and types of functionalities can effectively regulate the charge separation rate. For example, a combination of electron-accepting and electron-donating functionalities to create a bipolar property in GO may substantially enhance charge separation. For photocatalysis or photovoltaics, creation or deposition of electron and/or hole sinks on the surface of GO materials is essential for further interaction of the charges with the chemical species in the fluid phase. By coupling with appropriate electron and/or hole sinks, GO materials of high PL efficiency can be converted to powerful photocatalytic or photovoltaic materials. Further unraveling the charge transport mechanism in GO can be accomplished by the elaborate integration of analyses on PL, photovoltaic and photocatalysis measurement results. The above directions of further investigation underlie foundations for GO to serve as a platform material for highly efficient photoenergy conversion.

When combined with GO sheets, iNGOQDs exhibited improved stability in the same photocatalytic system.(230) Further design of the framework and electronic structure in GO-based composites to exploit GO sheets for electron trapping is expected to prolong the lifespan of a photocatalytic system.
